critique: This executive order, issued by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1934, addresses work assignments in the wool textile industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act. It establishes a Wool Textile Work Assignment Board to administer regulations preventing the improper speeding up of work and increased workloads. The order aims to balance employer efficiency with employee well-being, reflecting a moderate interventionist approach during the New Deal era. It doesn't directly address immigration, executive power significantly, federalism, national security, or social inclusion. However, it does lean towards government intervention in economic regulation to protect workers' rights.
